metadata.case_name: Sugar Manufacturers (Appellants) v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: Appellants are manufacturers of sugar who challenged notification dated 28-6-1967 issued by Central Government under clause 7 of Sugar Control Order, 1966, fixing ex-factory prices for specified sugar factories.
Initial fixation of sugar prices by notification dated 1-2-1967, followed by final fixation on 28-6-1967.

Writ petitions filed in Delhi High Court for quashing the impugned notification and mandamus; judgments and orders dated 10th October 1967 and 5th February 1968 dismissing writs; appeals certified fit under Article 133(1)(c) of Constitution.
Sugar Enquiry Commission Report October 1965 provided schedules of cost for price fixation; recommended five zones for country.
Government divided country into 22 zones for price fixation; Saraswati Industrial Syndicate (Haryana) claimed inefficiency due to same zone as Madhya Pradesh despite higher efficiency and wages.
Ex-factory price for Punjab including Haryana fixed at Rs. 137.35 per quintal on 24th March 1966, revised to Rs. 134.55 on 20th October 1966.

Counter-affidavit by Shri K. L. Pasricha, Joint Secretary, Ministry of Food, explaining price fixation based on estimates at start of season, revisions after; no provision for adjustment for prior deliveries.
Prices revised on 28-6-1967 for various regions e.g., Haryana 142.25, Madhya Pradesh 171.91 per quintal.
No demand made by appellants to Government for adjustments before approaching court.
Undertaking by Union of India in High Court to pay balance to Saraswati Industrial Syndicate if price found too low, exhausted with dismissal of writ.

legal_issues.text: Correctness of method adopted in fixing prices of sugar under clause 7 of Sugar Control Order, 1966, including zoning and failure to adjust for initial price fixation on 1-2-1967.
Whether Government required to make adjustments or allowances in final fixation of 28-6-1967 for prior deliveries at initial price.
Whether price fixation must follow exactly Sugar Enquiry Commission schedules, e.g., 5 zones, specific cost heads like excise duty.
Nature of price fixation: legislative or quasi-judicial, requiring hearing or natural justice.

petitioner_arguments.text: Government divided country into 22 zones instead of 5 recommended by Commission; inequitable zoning e.g., Haryana with Madhya Pradesh ignoring higher wages and efficiency of appellant.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Clause 7 Sugar Control Order 1966; Sugar Enquiry Commission Report

petitioner_arguments.text: No adjustment in final fixation of 28-6-1967 for losses on deliveries between 1-2-1967 and 28-6-1967 at lower initial price.
Prices not determined per Commission schedules: excluded excise duty, used wrong recovery basis, working days.
Provisional fixation on 1-2-1967 required final adjustment for whole season.

respondent_arguments.text: Clause 7 requires fixing price 'having regard to' estimated cost per Commission schedules, not mandatory adherence; no obligation for adjustments for prior fixations.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Clause 7 Sugar Control Order 1966; Ryots of Garabandho v. Zemindar of Parlakimedi

respondent_arguments.text: Price fixation from time to time based on estimates at season start, revised after; practice followed since 1963; appellants benefited previously.
Zoning and cost items discretionary; schedules are guidelines, not rigid; excise duty not part of manufacturing cost.
Price fixation legislative, not quasi-judicial; no hearing required.

court_reasoning.text: 'Having regard to' obliges consideration of relevant material but not strict adherence; no mandatory duty for adjustments compensating prior fixations.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Expression 'having regard to' only obliges Govt. to consider as relevant data material to which it must have regard.

court_reasoning.text: More zones than 5 recommended ok; encourages efficiency; Haryana appellant's efficiency offsets higher wages.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Modern manufacturer gains from price profitable for less efficient ones.

court_reasoning.text: Schedules are guidelines with elasticity; items like excise duty not necessarily manufacturing cost; no All India or 5-zone mandate.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Criteria elastic enough to include or exclude items.

court_reasoning.text: Price fixation legislative measure, not quasi-judicial; no natural justice breach; must be reasonable with nexus to purposes.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Price fixation more in nature of legislative measure.

court_reasoning.text: No prior demand to Govt.; no retrospective effect; Section 15 Essential Commodities Act protects good faith actions; no losses asserted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No allegation of lack of good faith.

holdings.text: Clause 7 permits price fixation from time to time without adjustments for prior periods; no mandatory duty breached.
No writ issues without demand and refusal; fixation not ultra vires or unreasonable.
Price fixation legislative; no hearing required if reasonable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ryots of Garabandho and other Villages v. Zemindar of Parlakimedi
precedents_cited.relevance: Meaning of 'having regard to' as obliging consideration of relevant material.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shree Meenakshi Mills Ltd v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Price fixation under control orders; reasonableness; fair price for consumer, reasonable profit.

precedents_cited.case_name: Panipat Cooperative Sugar Mills v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Sugar price fixation; unit-wise fixation perpetuates inefficiency; fair price ensures reasonable return.

precedents_cited.case_name: Premier Automobiles Ltd. v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Concept of fair prices varies; not applicable due to special agreement.

statutes_cited.name: Sugar Control Order, 1966
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to fix ex-factory prices having regard to estimated cost per Sugar Enquiry Commission schedules; from time to time.

statutes_cited.name: Essential Commodities Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Issued Sugar Control Order; protection for good faith actions in price fixation.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certification for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upholding Delhi High Court dismissal of writ petitions challenging sugar price notifications under Sugar Control Order, 1966; no breach of mandatory duty or unreasonableness found.

key_quotes.text: The expression 'having regard to' only obliges the Govt. to consider as relevant data material to which it must have regard.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets scope of clause 7(2); limits judicial review.

key_quotes.text: Price fixation is more in the nature of a legislative measure even though it may be based upon objective criteria.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Determines no quasi-judicial procedure or natural justice required.

key_quotes.text: A modern manufacturer of sugar, with more efficient methods of production, would gain by a fixation of price which was profitable even for less efficient manufacturers.
key_quotes.speaker: court
